SpNote.title: Site Quality
SpNote.note:
The Site Quality component below specifies the weather conditions that will affect the MSB's scheduling.
Weather Band: ------------- By default, "Allocated" is selected. This means your MSB may be scheduled when conditions match the range of tau allocated to you by your national TAG.
You can, if you wish, schedule your MSBs in subsets of your allocated time. For example, if you were allocated Band 2 (0.05<tau<0.08) you may request a tau range of 0.05<tau<0.06 for an MSB that needs to be observed on the upper end of the scale.
DO NOT REQUEST A TAU OUTSIDE YOUR TAG ALLOCATION. Your MSB will never be carried out if you do, since the scheduling software requires firstly, that the current tau is within your TAG allocation and then, only once this condition has been met, that the current tau is within your range of personal preference.
For those who best think in bands, the tau range of the JCMT Bands are:
Band 1: tau<0.05 Band 2: 0.05<tau<0.08 Band 3: 0.08<tau<0.12 Band 4: 0.12<tau<0.20 Band 5: 0.2<tau
The field labeled "tau for noise calculation" has a value that is used in other components for the RMS noise estimation of your observation. Change it if it does not represent the typical value of your allocation.
Seeing ------ This is the submillimetre seeing in arcseconds. The general recommendation is for you to use:
<=0.5 for polarimetry observations <=1.0 for photometry observations
and "Don't Care" for maps.

This MSB provides an example of photometry at 850/450 um. Two observations are combined within the MSB: a calibration and a science observation.
The following parameters have been set: - the on-source bolometers have been set to H7 on the LONG array and C14 on the SHORT array, with the 850W/450W um filter wheel setting selected (by way of the SCUBA component). Both the calibration and the science observations will inherit this setup - a chop throw of 60" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence). Note that there is a chop iterator in each observation (calibration and science target). These should match, and therefore if you chose to change the value of one, you should also change the value of the other - 6 integrations (set in the PHOTOM eye) and 40 integrations in the calibration/science observations accordingly
A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual scheduling and sequencing of the calibration observation, including the choice of calibrator to be observed, will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer. This will depend upon which calibrators are available and when the last FOCUS/SKYDIPs were made. It is possible to request a specific calibrator by including TARGET INFORMATION within the calibration observation.
SpNote.title: A calibrated 850/450 um photometry observation

SpNote.note:
In the pointing "eye" below, "auto-target" is selected (ticked) by default. This means that when your MSB is carried out, the TSS/observer will pick an appropriate pointing source at their discretion.
If you want to point on your source because you know for a fact that it is bright enough, has accurate coordinates and is not extended, simply untick the auto-target box. Your pointing will then be done at whatever coordinates are specified in the Target component.
SpNote.title: Pointing information
Site Quality
SpNote.note:
The Site Quality component below specifies the weather conditions that will affect the MSB's scheduling.
Weather Band: ------------- By default, "Allocated" is selected. This means your MSB may be scheduled when conditions match the range of tau allocated to you by your national TAG.
You can, if you wish, schedule your MSBs in subsets of your allocated time. For example, if you were allocated Band 2 (0.05<tau<0.08) you may request a tau range of 0.05<tau<0.06 for an MSB that needs to be observed on the upper end of the scale.
DO NOT REQUEST A TAU OUTSIDE YOUR TAG ALLOCATION. Your MSB will never be carried out if you do, since the scheduling software requires firstly, that the current tau is within your TAG allocation and then, only once this condition has been met, that the current tau is within your range of personal preference.

<=0.5 for polarimetry observations <=1.0 for photometry observations
and "Don't Care" for maps.

This MSB provides an example of 2 bolometer photometry at 850/450 um. Two observations are combined within the MSB: a calibration and a science observation.
The following parameters have been set: - the on-source bolometers have been set to H7 and H9 on the LONG array (the 450um bolometers will be selected automatically) and the 850W/450W um filter wheel setting selected (by way of the SCUBA component). Both the calibration and the science observations will inherit this setup - a chop throw of 60" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence). Note that there is a chop iterator in each observation (calibration and science target). These should match, and therefore if you chose to change the value of one, you should also change the value of the other - 6 integrations (set in the PHOTOM eye) and 40 integrations in the calibration/science observations accordingly
A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual scheduling and sequencing of the calibration observation, including the choice of calibrator to be observed, will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer. This will depend upon which calibrators are available and when the last FOCUS/SKYDIPs were made. It is possible to request a specific calibrator by including TARGET INFORMATION within the calibration observation.
SpNote.title: A calibrated 850/450 um photometry observation

SpNote.note:
In the pointing "eye" below, "auto-target" is selected (ticked) by default. This means that when your MSB is carried out, the TSS/observer will pick an appropriate pointing source at their discretion.
If you want to point on your source because you know for a fact that it is bright enough, has accurate coordinates and is not extended, simply untick the auto-target box. Your pointing will then be done at whatever coordinates are specified in the Target component.
SpNote.title: Pointing information

SpMSB.title: 850/450 um jiggle map (fully sampled at both 850/450 um)

SpNote.title: Site Quality
SpNote.note:
The Site Quality component below specifies the weather conditions that will affect the MSB's scheduling.
Weather Band: ------------- By default, "Allocated" is selected. This means your MSB may be scheduled when conditions match the range of tau allocated to you by your national TAG.
You can, if you wish, schedule your MSBs in subsets of your allocated time. For example, if you were allocated Band 2 (0.05<tau<0.08) you may request a tau range of 0.05<tau<0.06 for an MSB that needs to be observed on the upper end of the scale.
DO NOT REQUEST A TAU OUTSIDE YOUR TAG ALLOCATION. Your MSB will never be carried out if you do, since the scheduling software requires firstly, that the current tau is within your TAG allocation and then, only once this condition has been met, that the current tau is within your range of personal preference.
For those who best think in bands, the tau range of the JCMT Bands are:
Band 1: tau<0.05 Band 2: 0.05<tau<0.08 Band 3: 0.08<tau<0.12 Band 4: 0.12<tau<0.20 Band 5: 0.2<tau
The field labeled "tau for noise calculation" has a value that is used in other components for the RMS noise estimation of your observation. Change it if it does not represent the typical value of your allocation.
Seeing ------ This is the submillimetre seeing in arcseconds. The general recommendation is for you to use:
<=0.5 for polarimetry observations <=1.0 for photometry observations
and "Don't Care" for maps.

This MSB provides an example of the jiggle map mode at 850/450 um, producing fully sampled maps at both short and long wavelengths. Data from both the LONG and SHORT arrays will be stored. Two observations are combined within the MSB: a calibration and a science observation.
The following parameters have been set: - the 850W/450W um filter wheel setting selected (by way of the SCUBA component). Both the calibration and the science observations will inherit this setup - a 64-position jiggle to realise fully sampled maps with both the LONG and SHORT arrays - a chop throw of 120" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence). Note that there is a chop iterator in each observation (calibration and science target). These should match, and therefore if you chose to change the value of one, you should also change the value of the other - 2 jiggles (set in the JIGGLE eye) and 10 jiggles in the calibration/science observations respectively
A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual scheduling and sequencing of the calibration observation, including the choice of calibrator to be observed, will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer. This will depend upon which calibrators are available and when the last FOCUS/SKYDIPs were made. It is possible to request a specific calibrator by including TARGET INFORMATION within the calibration observation.
SpNote.title: A calibrated 850/450 um jiggle map observation, fully sampled at both 850/450 um

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration of the jiggle map observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. Data from both the LONG and SHORT arrays will be stored, with the 850W/450W um filter selected. A 64-position jiggle pattern will be employed to obtain a fully sampled map at both LONG and SHORT wavelengths. A number of parameters have been assumed/predetermined, as listed below: - maps map with both arrays will be fully sampled - a chop throw of 120" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence) - 2 integrations (set in the JIGGLE eye) A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Jiggle map calibration

SpObs.title: 850/450 um jiggle map (fully sampled at both 850/450 um )

SpNote.note:
In the pointing "eye" below, "auto-target" is selected (ticked) by default. This means that when your MSB is carried out, the TSS/observer will pick an appropriate pointing source at their discretion.
If you want to point on your source because you know for a fact that it is bright enough, has accurate coordinates and is not extended, simply untick the auto-target box. Your pointing will then be done at whatever coordinates are specified in the Target component.

This MSB provides an example of the jiggle map mode at 850/450 um, producing fully sampled maps with the LONG array ONLY. Data from both the LONG and SHORT arrays will be stored. Two observations are combined within the MSB: a calibration and a science observation.
The following parameters have been set: - the 850W/450W um filter wheel setting selected (by way of the SCUBA component). Both the calibration and the science observations will inherit this setup - a 16-position jiggle to realise a fully sampled maps with the LONG array ONLY - a chop throw of 120" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence). Note that there is a chop iterator in each observation (calibration and science target). These should match, and therefore if you chose to change the value of one, you should also change the value of the other - 2 jiggles (set in the JIGGLE eye) and 10 jiggles in the calibration/science observations respectively
A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual scheduling and sequencing of the calibration observation, including the choice of calibrator to be observed, will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer. This will depend upon which calibrators are available and when the last FOCUS/SKYDIPs were made. It is possible to request a specific calibrator by including TARGET INFORMATION within the calibration observation.

Site Quality
SpNote.note:

Weather Band: ------------- By default, "Allocated" is selected. This means your MSB may be scheduled when conditions match the range of tau allocated to you by your national TAG.

This observation provides an example of a calibrated scan map observation using the LONG and SHORT arrays, with the filter wheel set at the 850W/450W um position. The standard Emerson2 chop sequence has been assumed here, with 2 chop angles at each of 3 different chop throws. A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence, in addition to the specific choice of calibrator, will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: A calibrated 850/450 um scan map observation

SpNote.note:
In the pointing "eye" below, "auto-target" is selected (ticked) by default. This means that when your MSB is carried out, the TSS/observer will pick an appropriate pointing source at their discretion.
If you want to point on your source because you know for a fact that it is bright enough, has accurate coordinates and is not extended, simply untick the auto-target box. Your pointing will then be done at whatever coordinates are specified in the Target component.
SpNote.title: Pointing information
Site Quality
SpNote.note:
The Site Quality component below specifies the weather conditions that will affect the MSB's scheduling.
Weather Band: ------------- By default, "Allocated" is selected. This means your MSB may be scheduled when conditions match the range of tau allocated to you by your national TAG.
You can, if you wish, schedule your MSBs in subsets of your allocated time. For example, if you were allocated Band 2 (0.05<tau<0.08) you may request a tau range of 0.05<tau<0.06 for an MSB that needs to be observed on the upper end of the scale.
DO NOT REQUEST A TAU OUTSIDE YOUR TAG ALLOCATION. Your MSB will never be carried out if you do, since the scheduling software requires firstly, that the current tau is within your TAG allocation and then, only once this condition has been met, that the current tau is within your range of personal preference.
For those who best think in bands, the tau range of the JCMT Bands are:
Band 1: tau<0.05 Band 2: 0.05<tau<0.08 Band 3: 0.08<tau<0.12 Band 4: 0.12<tau<0.20 Band 5: 0.2<tau
The field labeled "tau for noise calculation" has a value that is used in other components for the RMS noise estimation of your observation. Change it if it does not represent the typical value of your allocation.
Seeing ------ This is the submillimetre seeing in arcseconds. The general recommendation is for you to use:
<=0.5 for polarimetry observations <=1.0 for photometry observations
and "Don't Care" for maps.

This observation provides an example of a calibrated fast scan map observation using the LONG array, with the filter wheel set at the 850W/450W um position. The standard Emerson2 chop sequence has been assumed here, with 2 chop angles at each of 3 different chop throws. A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence, in addition to the specific choice of calibrator, will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
For fast scanning, we scan at 1 arcmin/minute (rather than 24 arcsec/sec) corresponding to a sample spacing of 7.5 arcsec. Additionally the array is moved 2 arcmin between scans.
SpNote.title: A calibrated 850 um fast scan map observation

SpNote.note:
In the pointing "eye" below, "auto-target" is selected (ticked) by default. This means that when your MSB is carried out, the TSS/observer will pick an appropriate pointing source at their discretion.
If you want to point on your source because you know for a fact that it is bright enough, has accurate coordinates and is not extended, simply untick the auto-target box. Your pointing will then be done at whatever coordinates are specified in the Target component.
SpNote.title: Pointing information
Instrumental polarization observation notes
SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of the sequence of tasks required to make a measurement of the instrumental polarization at 850 um.This is one of the rare examples when a calibration source needs to be defined explicitly. An unpolarized source is required, ideally either Mars or Uranus (a little small, angular size-wise). In this example all polarization angles are measured for a single chop throw before moving to the next chop setting. A pointing, z-focus and repoint are also include (POINTING eye and FOCUS respectively) as is a skydip.

SpNote.title: Instrumental polarization observation notes
SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of the sequence of tasks required to make a measurement of the instrumental polarization at 450 um.This is one of the rare examples when a calibration source needs to be defined explicitly. An unpolarized source is required, ideally either Mars or Uranus (a little small, angular size-wise). In this example all polarization angles are measured for a single chop throw before moving to the next chop setting. A pointing, z-focus and repoint are also include (POINTING eye and FOCUS respectively) as is a skydip.

SpNote.title: scan map flatfielding
SpNote.note: This observation specifies an observation used to calculate the flatfield using a scan map observation where the scan overlap is small enough to enable a fully-sampled image of the beam to be generated for each bolometer on the array. The observation must be done in extremely stable conditions (both for tau and seeing). Only relative calibration matters for a flatfield. Make sure that the telescope is focussed but there is no need for an accurate absolute flux calibration. Note that we use EKH scanning here - emersonII scanning would take to long. This observation requires a point source target (uranus is selected by default).

The Site Quality component below specifies the weather conditions that will affect the MSB's scheduling.
Weather Band: ------------- By default, "Allocated" is selected. This means your MSB may be scheduled when conditions match the range of tau allocated to you by your national TAG.
You can, if you wish, schedule your MSBs in subsets of your allocated time. For example, if you were allocated Band 2 (0.05<tau<0.08) you may request a tau range of 0.05<tau<0.06 for an MSB that needs to be observed on the upper end of the scale.
DO NOT REQUEST A TAU OUTSIDE YOUR TAG ALLOCATION. Your MSB will never be carried out if you do, since the scheduling software requires firstly, that the current tau is within your TAG allocation and then, only once this condition has been met, that the current tau is within your range of personal preference.
For those who best think in bands, the tau range of the JCMT Bands are:
Band 1: tau<0.05 Band 2: 0.05<tau<0.08 Band 3: 0.08<tau<0.12 Band 4: 0.12<tau<0.20 Band 5: 0.2<tau
The field labeled "tau for noise calculation" has a value that is used in other components for the RMS noise estimation of your observation. Change it if it does not represent the typical value of your allocation.
Seeing ------ This is the submillimetre seeing in arcseconds. The general recommendation is for you to use:
<=0.5 for polarimetry observations <=1.0 for photometry observations
and "Don't Care" for maps.
SpNote.title: Site Quality

SpNote.note:
Polarimetry observations can use standard flux calibration observations (make sure that you match chop throws!). These library MSBs do include standard flux calibration. If you don't want your polarimetry observations flux calibrated, you are welcome to remove the calibration observations before submitting.
There is usually no need to provide an instrumental polarization observation as part of an MSB since the IP is extremely stable. If you really want to do an IP observation two examples are present in the miscellaneous procedures library.
Alternatively, feel free to add a note for the observer to indicate that you would like an IP observation if one has not been done recently. (The TSS will have access to standard observations such as those for obtaining the IP).
The 450um IPs are uncertain. Please talk to your support scientist before attempting a 450um polarimetry observation.
SpNote.title: Flux calibrations and IP
Site Quality
SpNote.note:
The Site Quality component below specifies the weather conditions that will affect the MSB's scheduling.

and "Don't Care" for maps.

A 850 (and simulataneously 450-) micron photometry polarimetry observation using 16 waveplate positions and a chop throw of 120 arcsec. There are 6 integrations for each waveplate position. Includes an optional flux calibration observation.
SpNote.title: 850um phot pol

SpNote.note:
In the pointing "eye" below, "auto-target" is selected (ticked) by default. This means that when your MSB is carried out, the TSS/observer will pick an appropriate pointing source at their discretion.
If you want to point on your source because you know for a fact that it is bright enough, has accurate coordinates and is not extended, simply untick the auto-target box. Your pointing will then be done at whatever coordinates are specified in the Target component.
SpNote.title: Pointing information

SpLibraryFolder.title: SCUBA polarimetry MSBs: jiggle map mode

SpMSB.title: 850 um pol jiggle map (fully sampled 850, under-sampled 450um)

and "Don't Care" for maps.

This observation contains a flux calibration for 850 and 450 microns, and a polarimetry observations at 850 microns. The translator will ensure that 450 micron data is saved even though the data will be under-sampled initially (since each map is usually repeated a number of times the 450 micron data will eventually fill in the gaps as the sky rotates).
This observation uses 16 waveplate positions and a 150 arcsec chop throw.
SpNote.title: Jiggle map polarimetry

SpNote.note: This observation provides an example of calibration of the jiggle map observing mode. Here, the choice of calibration source and precise scheduling of the calibration observation is left to the discretion of the observer/TSS. Data from both the LONG and SHORT arrays will be stored, with the 850W/450W um filter selected. A 64-position jiggle pattern will be employed to obtain a fully sampled map at both LONG and SHORT wavelengths. A number of parameters have been assumed/predetermined, as listed below: - maps map with both arrays will be fully sampled - a chop throw of 120" in azimuth (set in CHOP sequence) - 2 integrations (set in the JIGGLE eye) A pointing, z-focus and repoint will be made prior to the calibration observation (POINTING and FOCUS eyes respectively), as will a skydip (SKYDIP eye). The actual sequence will be determined at the time of observing by the TSS/observer, depending on when the last focus/SKYDIPs were made.
SpNote.title: Jiggle map calibration

SpObs.title: 850um pol jiggle map (fully sampled 850, under-sampled 450 um )

SpNote.note:
In the pointing "eye" below, "auto-target" is selected (ticked) by default. This means that when your MSB is carried out, the TSS/observer will pick an appropriate pointing source at their discretion.
If you want to point on your source because you know for a fact that it is bright enough, has accurate coordinates and is not extended, simply untick the auto-target box. Your pointing will then be done at whatever coordinates are specified in the Target component.
SpNote.title: Pointing information

SpLibraryFolder.title: SCUBA polarimetry MSBs: scan map mode

SpNote.title: Site Quality
SpNote.note:
The Site Quality component below specifies the weather conditions that will affect the MSB's scheduling.
Weather Band: ------------- By default, "Allocated" is selected. This means your MSB may be scheduled when conditions match the range of tau allocated to you by your national TAG.
You can, if you wish, schedule your MSBs in subsets of your allocated time. For example, if you were allocated Band 2 (0.05<tau<0.08) you may request a tau range of 0.05<tau<0.06 for an MSB that needs to be observed on the upper end of the scale.
DO NOT REQUEST A TAU OUTSIDE YOUR TAG ALLOCATION. Your MSB will never be carried out if you do, since the scheduling software requires firstly, that the current tau is within your TAG allocation and then, only once this condition has been met, that the current tau is within your range of personal preference.
For those who best think in bands, the tau range of the JCMT Bands are:
Band 1: tau<0.05 Band 2: 0.05<tau<0.08 Band 3: 0.08<tau<0.12 Band 4: 0.12<tau<0.20 Band 5: 0.2<tau
The field labeled "tau for noise calculation" has a value that is used in other components for the RMS noise estimation of your observation. Change it if it does not represent the typical value of your allocation.
Seeing ------ This is the submillimetre seeing in arcseconds. The general recommendation is for you to use:
<=0.5 for polarimetry observations <=1.0 for photometry observations
and "Don't Care" for maps.

This is a fast scan map polarimetry observation at 850 microns using the EmersonII scanning technique. It is important that an image is obtained for each waveplate position as soon as possible, it is for this reason that we do 4 chopped scan maps between each movement of the waveplate whilst scanning as fast as we can - no 450 micron data will be obtained in this mode.
Only 4 waveplate positions are used. The order is 0, 45, 22.5, 67.5 in order to obtain a single Q or U Stokes parameter in the shortest possible time.
SpNote.title: Scan map polarimetry

SpNote.note: Scan map polarimetry is a difficult observing mode in which to obtain high quality data. The limiting factor becomes that of sky variability. In this mode we have assumed that it is optimal to make 4 raster scans instead of the usual 6 that are employed for the Emerson2 scanning scheme, and that the 4 scans are made for each of the polarization grid angles. Under some circumstances it may be preferable to make observations at each of the grid angles before moving to a different scan throw/angle.

In the pointing "eye" below, "auto-target" is selected (ticked) by default. This means that when your MSB is carried out, the TSS/observer will pick an appropriate pointing source at their discretion.
If you want to point on your source because you know for a fact that it is bright enough, has accurate coordinates and is not extended, simply untick the auto-target box. Your pointing will then be done at whatever coordinates are specified in the Target component.
SpNote.title: Pointing information
